frameDefinitions: In this frame a Deformer deforms a Patient possibly against a Resistant_surface such that it undergoes a shape-change from its canonical or original shape into the Configuration, a new shape.
An Agent ceases an Activity without completing it. '' 'After the lawsuit, the company stopped producing the once very profitable toy.'
A Grower endeavors to tend to and influence the environment of Food so as to foster its growth.
A Theme moves with respect to a Fixed_location, generally with a certain Periodicity, without undergoing unbounded translational motion or significant alteration of configuration/shape.
This frame contains words for motions or actions an Agent performs using some part of his/her body.

An Agent causes a Theme to move with respect to a certain Fixed_location, generally with a certain Periodicity, without undergoing unbounded translational motion or significant alteration of configuration/shape.
frameExamples: Ellen <t>crumpled</t> the paper into a ball.
After the lawsuit, the company <t>stopped</t> producing the once very profitable toy.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Deformer</fen> is the one who does the reshaping.
The <fen>Patient</fen> is the entity acted on and that undergoes a change.
The <fen>Cause</fen> is an animate or inanimate entity, a force, or event that produces an effect. Volitionality is not a necessary characteristic of <fen>Cause</fen>s.
A state that holds of the <fen>Patient</fen> or a relation that holds among the constituent parts of the <fen>Patient</fen> as a result of the arranging action.
The role <fen>Time</fen> identifies when the <fen>Deformer</fen> intentionally affects the <fen>Patient</fen>.
The <fen>Place</fen> indicates where the <fen>Deformer</fen> intentionally affects the <fen>Patient</fen>.
This role identifies <fen>Agent</fen> that stops the <fen>Activity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Activity</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> stops.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> stops the <fen>Activity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> stops the <fen>Activity</fen>.
The <fen>Grower</fen> is the agent growing <fen>Food</fen>.

<fex name='Food'>Food</fex> is the item grown by the <fen>Grower</fen>, which can include things not traditionally eaten, like flowers, etc., or items for other consumption-related uses, like medicines, smokables, etc.
When the growing event occurs.
The greater geographic location where the <fen>Grower</fen> grows <fen>Food</fen>.
A physical entity that is participating in non-translational motion.
The time at which the <fen>Theme</fen> is in bounded motion.
The location where the bounded motion happens.
The <fen>Agent</fen> uses some part of his/her body to perform the action. <fen>Agent</fen> occurs as the External Argument.
With some verbs in this frame, the <fen>Body_part</fen> involved in the action is specified by the meaning of the verb and cannot be expressed separately.  For example,
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the body movement occurs.
The location within which the movement of a <fen>Body_part</fen> takes place.
<fen>Theme</fen> identifies the object involved in motion.
The <fen>Agent</fen> performs the intentional act.
This role identifies the part of the Agent's body being used to manipulate the <fen>Theme</fen>.
<fen>Cause</fen> identifies the non-agentive force that causes the motion in place.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the event occurs.
This role  identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the event occurs.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The lieutenant</fex> crushed it angrily with his boot before looking back at Hencke.
Jack plucked the flower out of his morning coat and closed his fist slowly over it , crushing <fex>it</fex> into a pulp.
<fex>The strong winds</fex> deformed the structure of the outhouse.
The lieutenant crushed it angrily with his boot <fex>before looking back at Hencke</fex>.
There was singing for joy in the streets, and <fex>everywhere</fex> people lifting their arms into the air.
Kim twirled the glass <fex>in his fingers</fex>.

passageCandidateSpans.text: Sprained Ankle – American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons
